abstract_summ: Increasing evidences show that SARS‐CoV‐2 is not always confined to the respiratory tract but can also invade the central nervous system (CNS) and induce neurological diseases.The patient was found to have subarachnoid hemorrhage and later tested positive for COVID-19.The main tropism of the novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‐19) is respiratory.AIHA is characterized by the destruction of red cells by autoantibodies, but the mechanism underpinning autoimmunity in COVID-19 patients has yet to be elucidated.This Journal recently published two papers describing autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) associated with severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection (1, 2).The novel coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has had a profound impact on healthcare systems around the world.
title_summ: Is molecular mimicry the culprit in the autoimmune haemolytic anaemia affecting patients with COVID‐19?Novel Coronavirus Disease 2019 and Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: A Case ReportEncephalopathy in patients with COVID‐19: ‘Causality or coincidence?’
